Title: Pietro’s Pizza
Content:
The Pizza Man of Kauai - Tom Iannucci When most people think of “pizza” and “Hawai‘i” they think of pineapple and ham. Tom Iannucci thinks about brick ovens and learning more from his peers at the Association of Verace Pizza Napoletana, who commissioned his pizzeria as their first certified pizzeria in Hawai‘i.

It all started on Long Island, New York, where Tom grew up. “It wasn’t the best neighborhood,” says Tom. “A lot of my buddies were going to jail, so after the Beirut bombing in 1983, I joined the Marines. I met my wife, D’lissa, in Tokyo and meeting her changed my life.”

“I actually ended up stationed at the embassy in Beirut as part of the Marine Diplomatic Security Force. One day, when the phones actually worked I called D’lissa, who grew up on Kaua‘i and she asked me, ‘what’s it going to be? New York or Hawai‘i?’ At that point, Hawai‘i sounded really good.”

Iannucci’s first stay in Kaua‘i only lasted a month. “Coming from where I did, it was too quiet, too soon. So we moved to O‘ahu for four years before returning. When we did, I threw myself into the community. I became an Assistant Pastor for Calvary Chapel, visited prisons and spoke at many schools.”

But through this period, something was missing: Pizza.

“I couldn’t eat the pizza in Hawai‘i. I drove my wife crazy making pizzas in our little apartment’s oven. I started calling pizza parlors in New York City asking for advice. Most weren’t very friendly, but I persisted. I installed a gas oven in my carport and began to host big pizza parties for the kids. Eventually, I built a brick oven in the driveway and started delivering the pizzas to the neighbors, and even making them for the police and fire stations.”

Iannucci traveled the world chasing his passion. On a trip to Naples, he fell in love with Neapolitan style pizza, a method that involves a pizza that is cooked in brick ovens at temperatures in excess of 900 degrees for as little as 90 seconds. “For my 50th birthday, my wife asked me what I wanted,” Iannucci remembers. “I said ‘I want to go to the International Pizza Expo in Las Vegas.’ It was there that Iannucci found his lost tribe. “They were all speaking my language!” 

With the brick oven he built from scratch, he started making pizzas by the dozen. “People told me for years I needed to open a restaurant, but it wasn’t until I woke up one day with three kids in college, and trying to get by on a pastor’s salary that I actually decided to take the advice.”

With a little financial help from his friend and partner Dave Erickson, and after 32 years of assimilating to local culture, Iannucci opened Pietro’s in August 2015 on Rice Street in Līhu‘e. Shortly after, the current front location became available, and that opened in May of 2016. “We sold out every day for two weeks,” says Iannucci, “We were so busy, I couldn’t even get the Neapolitan side open until August.” Pietro’s was even the “Editor’s Choice” for Best New Restaurant in Hawaii Magazine’s “Best of the Best” in 2018. 

In April, Iannucci launched a new restaurant and lounge at the Poipu Shopping Village named Pietro’s Pizza e Pasta. “It’s four times larger than the original, and features pasta as well as pizza.” The new Pietro’s is also more diversified in that it features live music in the lounge. “The showcase will always be pizza,” says Iannucci, “but I want to work on sauces, new pizzas and specialty dishes.

As a former resident of the New York City area, I ask Iannucci about the legend of New York water making for the best pizza doughs. “There’s truth to that,” he says, “but Kaua‘i has some of the best water in the world. Our water comes as natural artesian water that filters down from Mount Wai‘ale‘ale, where it rains 540 inches per year. I’ll put our water up against anyone’s.”

Lastly, I had to ask Iannucci about his favorite pizza. “I’m a meat lover—Portuguese sausage, cured meats, pepperoni chunks and add some jalapeno’s for a good kick. But our signature pizza is the pepperoni, aptly named The Don Pietro.”

For more information on Pietro’s, go to pietroskauai.com

Title: A Grand Wailea Luau
Content: Oceanfront at the Grand Wailea enjoy the magical enchantment of Honua’ula. Meet Pele, the goddess of fire, and Kananaka,  the mermaid of Maui, and step back into a journey filled with traditional chants and hula bringing the history of our island home to life. Luau includes and all you can eat buffet, hosted bar, imu ceremony and a chance to be on stage for a hula lesson.
Image Alt Text: Aha'aina Wailea, A Grand Wailea Luau

Title: Maui Escape Rooms
Content: Make your escape from the norm and take part in a unique indoor adventure. Test your wits in one of four themed rooms designed to tantalize your imagination! Team up with others to commit a successful Bank Heist, or match wits with a genius to learn Tesla’s Secret. Save the legendary Sherlock Holmes and find a way out of his booby-trapped apartment, or take part in a Prison Break and make a thrilling getaway. There’s an adventure for everyone!

Title: South Shore Tiki Lounge
Content: South Shore Tiki Lounge is a great place to unwind with some drinks and enjoy your night.  They’ve got a cool, retro Tiki theme and specialty cocktails including an assortment of Mai Tais, daiquiris, and other specialty house drinks that have people clamoring for more. Owners Alma Tassi and her husband Mikhail took over South Shore Tiki Lounge over a decade ago, seizing upon a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to purchase this venue and turn it into one of the coolest little places on Maui.

Title: VIBE Maui
Content: Vibe Maui has an ultra-modern, yet relaxed atmosphere with a speakeasy vibe (no pun intended) and thoughtfully crafted specialty cocktails. They also have regular live entertainment, taking pride in their support of local, upcoming artists. Owners Myline and Brandon Dahle traded in corporate life for a new start on Maui, and haven’t looked back.

Title: CJ's Deli & Diner
Content:
Since 2003, CJ’s Deli & Diner in Lahaina has been serving up generous portions of comfort food favorites. Plus they boast of having the most affordable breakfast in the Kaanapali area, served up daily from 7-11 a.m. All the familiar favorites are here, like pancakes and French toast, bacon, hash, bagels, omelets, acai bowls, with all their ingredients sourced locally.

Co-owners Christian Jorgensen (CJ) and his wife Marilyn have been delighting customers with delicious food and affordable prices. “We have so many repeat customers,” says Marilyn. “Many eat at our restaurant every day of their vacation.” The fun, friendly faces and great value are a huge draw, but it’s also the casual mom n’ pop vibe that keeps people coming back, including playful chalkboard menus, a family-friendly atmosphere and their BYOB policy.

Title: Semisub
Content: If you've ever wanted to experience the beauty beneath the waters around Hawai‘i, you would normally have to get snorkel gear or become certified in SCUBA. Fortunately, there's now an easier way to view the ocean's wonders. Semisub offers a means for anyone to peer beneath the sea from the comfort of a semi-submersible water vessel. The Semisub is a jet-powered catamaran with a special underwater viewing compartment from where you can see coral reefs, sea turtles and the occasional reef shark. An outing on the Semisub begins with a cruise along the Waikīkī skyline and Diamond Head in air-conditioned comfort. Once you reach your destination, the vessel partially submerges and the wonders below are revealed. Afterwards, return topside for a delicious meal by the esteemed and award-winning Chef Chai.

Title: Kukui Grove Center’s Kaua‘i Ocean Discovery
Content: Located at Kukui Grove Center in Līhu‘e, Kaua‘i Ocean Discovery is a new educational facility that shares the traditions and knowledge of our ocean connections and inspires stewardship. Tour the extensive Hawaiian archipelago, including Hawaiian Islands Humpback Whale National Marine Sanctuary and Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument, located to Kaua‘i’s northwest. Explore an underwater world through videos, interactive displays and hands-on activities. Little ones adore the ocean puppet theatre, and the facility is a few steps away from the Kukui Grove Keiki Korner play area, which is also ocean themed. Kaua‘i Ocean Discovery is presented by the National Marine Sanctuary Foundation and NOAA National Marine Sanctuaries with free admission to the public. Open 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Tues.-Thurs., 11 a.m.-7 p.m. Fri., 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Sat. Closed Mon. and Tues. Visit kukuigrovecenter.com for event schedule including visiting speakers, family activities and special themed programs and exhibits. A weekly Talk & Tour is hosted 10 a.m. every Thurs., led by a Program Specialist with the Hawaiian Islands Humpback Whale National Marine Sanctuary.      For special requests, to support or volunteer, call (808) 246-2861 or email jean.souza@noaa.gov.
Image Alt Text: Kukui Grove Center’s Kaua‘i Ocean Discovery - Kauai|

Title: The Pineapple Store
Content: With 30 years of customer satisfaction behind them, The Pineapple Store continues to offer USDA certified Hawai‘i-grown fruits and tropical flowers shipped to anywhere in the continental U.S. and Canada. You can also take them with you on the plane! Share the sweet island flavors and tropical blossoms of the islands with family and friends—pineapples picked from fields in ‘Ele‘ele on Kauai‘i, and O‘ahu and Maui; Solo or Sunrise varieties of papaya, each unique in flavor and color; special gift baskets filled with Kauai‘i coffee, chocolate-covered mac nuts, dried mango, cookies, fruit jams and more; and boxed tropical flowers from the Kaua‘i flower farm straight to your front door. It’s a natural that you’d also find fruit smoothies at The Pineapple Store! “Our focus is on the culture of Kaua‘i and the Hawaiian Islands where it’s all about family, friendship, love and respect,” agree Chucky and Christian Marston Sr., of The Pineapple Store. “When someone sends our products home to the Mainland, I hope a little bit of Kauai‘i and our culture goes with them.” Share a little of the Garden Isle with family and friends or take it home with you! Because of their location near Līhu‘e Airport, make it your first stop upon arrival and before departing the Garden Isle!

Title: Paradise Helicopters - Big Island
Content:
With the grandeur of Hawaii Island literally at your feet, Paradise Helicopters takes you above and and away for unforgettable views of waterfalls, valleys, volcanoes, coastlines and beaches. Forget the drone shots—personally experience the thrill of an aerial perspective as you soar above an incredible everchanging landscape. Add an extra thrill with the doors-off option!

Best of all, Paradise Helicopters offers a Carbon Offset Program if you wish to compensate for the greenhouse gases produced during your tour. One hundred percent of each carbon offset fee is used to plant endemic trees in Hawai‘i! Ask about it when reserving your flight.

Paradise Helicopters makes it convenient for you to fly from one of three airports. Custom charter flights are also available; just speak to one of their specialists who will craft your flight according to your specifications.

Book A Paradise Helicopters Tour Today!

Kona: Circle Island Experience

You flew all this way to Hawai‘i …shouldn't you see all of it? We certainly think so! That’s why we created the only complete helicopter tour around Hawai'i Island.

2 Hrs.

DETAILS

Kona: Experience Hawai'i

Enjoy a true Hawai‘i Experience on Paradise Helicopter’s premier air adventure. Explore all five volcanoes, hidden white and black sand beaches, and lush waterfalls.

1.75 Hrs.

DETAILS

Kona: Kohala Coast & Waterfalls

Fly with Paradise to the Kohala Valleys to hover amidst the breathtaking 2500’ waterfalls and sheer cliff faces.

1 Hr.

DETAILS

Kona: Kohala Coast Waterfalls & Remote Hike

Mid-flight your aircraft will touch down at a remote location deep in Kohala Mountains to explore and enjoy a moderate 0.5 mile pilot-led hike through a Guava (waiwi) forest.

2.5 Hrs.

DETAILS

Kona: Sunset Experience

Our Sunset Experience is the perfect way to cap off a day in paradise. You’ll see the gorgeous beaches tucked away below lava fields along the Kona and Kohala Coasts.

2.25 Hrs.

DETAILS

Kona: Volcano Kohala Landing

See the breathtaking beauty of Hawai‘i Island plus enjoy a very special landing in the Kohala area for total immersion into this historic region of the island on the Kohala Paradise Landing air adventure.

3.5 Hrs.

DETAILS

Waimea: Doors-off Kohala Valleys & Waterfalls

There is no better way to experience and learn about the geography, history and incomparable lush beauty of Kohala, birthplace of King Kamehameha, than our doors-off tour.

2.5 Hrs.

DETAILS

Waimea: Doors-off Kohala Waterfalls & Hike

The Doors-Off Kohala Waterfalls & Remote Hike is the first and only doors-off helicopter tour deep into the heart of the spectacular Kohala valleys.

2.25 Hrs.

DETAILS

Hilo: Lava & Rainforest Adventure

The Lava & Rainforests Adventure showcases the story of how Hawai‘i is inextricably linked to the elements. You will fly over Kīlauea, what was the most active volcano on earth.

1 Hr.

DETAILS

Title: ALOHA ADVENTURE FARMS
Content:
Venture to the Kona coffee mecca in Holualoa for a one-of-a-kind “aloha adventure.” 

“We’re the only company offering a Polynesian ATV or tiki carving adventure on the Big Island,” says Leiah Layton of Aloha Adventure Farms. “Guests figuratively visit the islands of Hawai‘i, Fiji, Tonga and Sāmoa. They participate in activities at each stop.” This is with the Polynesian ATV Adventure option.

On the Polynesian Carving Adventure, Layton says, “The tiki carving allows guests to sit with a master carver from Tonga, and create their own tiki from locally sourced wood.

“We believe in the spirit of aloha,” continues Layton. “we hope each guest leaves feeling like they are a part of Aloha Adventure Farms’ ‘ohana (family). We also hope they leave with a deeper understanding and appreciation for the people of Polynesia.”

Reservations are required and discounts are available.

Title: MY GENERATION SHOW
Content:
Enjoying live music is always a good way to spend a night of your vacation. “My Generation” is more than just music; it’s an immersive 10-performer rock n’ roll show, written and produced by Hawai‘i-based band, Lucky Tongue. 

Under an open-air “musiquarium,” you’ll experience a musical extravaganza featuring singers, dancers, stunning special effects and intricate choreography, all building to a moving, unforgettable finale. 

By night’s end, “My Generation” will have you convinced of the everlasting power of music. 

“The band wants to bring credence to the spirit of the many songs we have performed for years,” says band leader Blaine Ward. “The show is designed to bring the message in these songs to a new generation and make the content of the music top of mind.”

   My Generation is presented every Wednesday at 7 p.m. at the Blue Dragon Bar and Restaurant.

Title: Unique Maui Tours
Content:
You’re the VIP with your own customized guided tour in a comfortable, luxury SUV. The knowledgeable guides from Unique Maui Tours do all the driving, stopping when and where you want.

Driving all day isn’t your thing, you may want to hook up with Unique Maui Tours. Let their tour guide navigate the windy Hana roads while you relax and enjoy the breathtaking vistas. Their luxury SUVs can seat up to seven passengers and are more comfortable and offer better views than your standard tour vans.

Another perk to taking this trek with Unique Maui Tours is that they know all the best places to stop for food, take a dip in the ocean or snap some photos. This is your own private tour, so where you stop and what you do along the way is entirely up to you.
Tags: group tours|guided tour|island tour|private tour|scenic views

Title: da Playground
Content:
da Playground is a 4,000 square foot “Sports Barcade and Events Center” in Wailuku. "After being here for awhile, we saw that there was a lack of quality spaces for local artists,” says Myline. “So we created da Playground’ to seat 400 people for performance events. We’re able to do this by having games that are movable, like digital darts, cornhole and ping-pong tables. Plus we installed a 14-foot stage with professional sound and lighting.”

da Playground is designed for extreme flexibility. It will be popular for corporate parties and wedding receptions in addition to live shows.” da Playground will also feature a simple, high-quality food menu, the chef-owned 808 Bistro. While our food selections will be bar staples, our mission is to have each item be the best of its kind on the island.”

Title: Dreadz School of Surf Hawaii
Content:
As the saying goes, the family that plays together, stays together, and it seems they work together as well!

A former beach boy in the 80s and 90s, Chris "Dreadz" Chester, owner of Dreadz School of Surf Hawaii, met his wife Nadia while working. Both surfers have raised their three children in the sport as well—their oldest, Joshua, is a pro surfer currently competing in the World Surf League tour. Together, the family has a combined 35 years of surf experience.

The three siblings—Joshua, Nate and Chloe—provide surf lessons for the surf school, which include surfboards. Call to book individual or group lessons in Waikīkī or Kapolei.

Title: Salt and Pepper Cafe
Content:
Having owned several restaurants and nightclubs on the East Coast, owner Jeffrey Samuels wanted Salt & Pepper Cafe to be a comfortable spot serving good food to his customers. The cafe’s contemporary look and vibe is all Samuels.

“I designed the layout myself,” says Samuels. “I was looking for a place where everyone could enjoy a good meal. Like the meaning of Oʻahu—‘The Gathering Place’—I have friends who are vegans, who feel uncomfortable going out for a meal because they can’t find anything on the menu to eat. I wanted the cafe to be more upscale to attract a business lunch group.”

Samuels shares a few of his favorite items on the menu. “I enjoy the Impossible Burger because of the full flavor it offers,” says Samuels. “I also like the BBQ Sandwich and Vegan Loco Moco for the same reasons. We are one of a few restaurants that offer blue soft shell crab. I used to enjoy them when I lived on the East Coast.”

For the perfect dining experience, Samuels suggests including a few of the following in your order—Ube Stuffed French Toast, Vegan Loco Moco, Brussel Sprouts, Mama’s Meatloaf and any of the omelet dishes.

“I want the food to have that ‘Instagrammable’ look,” says Samuels, “but I also want to make sure I’ve exceeded our customers’ expectations, and can’t wait (for them) to recommend, and come back for more again and again.”

Title: Sunshine Arts
Content:
Go Where the Locals Go! This beautiful store gallery has everything you would want to explore for yourself and for the precious gift of giving. It has the largest collection of local art and collectibles. A must see and something for everyone! Discover Paintings, Ceramic, Wood Bowls, Photography, Stained Glass, Ornaments, Jewelry and so much more

This treasure of a place is nestled on the beautiful side of Windward Oahu. There are many one-of-a kind precious items to discover. Don't miss all the one-of-a kind finds here at Sunshine Arts! 

They also have a full service custom frame shop and will ship anywhere in the world. Preview some of the local art and collectibles they have at SunshineArts.net.

You can also check out their Waikiki Marriott location on Kalakaua by appointment only. 808-352-1824.

Title: Boss Frog's Snorkel, Surf & Cycle - Maui
Content:
Boss Frog’s Snorkel, Bike & Beach Rentals offers a morning snorkel trip to Molokini on a 55-foot power catamaran with stairs that lead you down into the water to get your snorkeling adventure off to an easy start. Snorkel gear, breakfast and lunch are included. Boss Frog’s also provides island information and booking discounts on other activities. Their nine storefront locations on Maui are well known for renting snorkel gear, surfboards, bodyboards, SUP boards, bicycles, underwater cameras and more.

Ma’alaea Harbor Shops

Phone Number: (808) 242-0088
Store Hours: 6:00am to 3:00pm Daily.
Address: 300 Ma’alaea Rd, Wailuku, HI 96793 (Building 2, Shop #2N)

Lahaina Front Street

Phone Number: (808) 856-4188
Store Hours: 8:00 am to 6:00 pm Daily.
Address: 150 Lahainaluna Road, Lahaina HI 96761

Ka’anapali

Store Hours: 8:00am to 5:00pm Daily.
Address: 3636 Lower Honoapiilani Road, Lahaina HI 96761

Napili

Store Hours: 8:00am to 5:00pm Daily.
Address: 5095 Napilihau Street in Napili Plaza, Napili HI 96761

Wailea

Store Hours: 8:00am to 5:00pm Daily.
Address: 2463 South Kihei Road, Suite A-15 in the Kamaole Center, Kihei HI 96753

Kahana

Store Hours: 8:00am to 5:00pm Daily.
Address: Kahana Manor, 4310 Lower Honoapiilani Road, Lahaina HI 96761

Title: Clark's Hawaii Tours - Kauai
Content: Clark’s Hawaii Tours offers visitors two ways to explore the Garden Isle. The four-hour Kauai History Tour begins at 9 a.m. and stops at five locations: ‘Ōpaeka‘a Falls, Hanapēpē River Valley Lookout, the famous Tree Tunnel, Kauai Coffee Co., Spouting Horn and Old Koloa Town. On ship days only, catch the hop-on, hop-off shuttle that operates 8 a.m.-4 p.m. out of Nāwiliwili Harbor.

Title: Crazy Shirts - Maui
Content: Famous for original quality t-shirt designs for over 50 years, Crazy Shirts casual apparel has modern styling from head to toe for men, women and children. Polo, pima cotton and long-sleeved shirts, twill cargo shorts, swimwear, jackets, dresses, accessories. Innovative dyes feature elements like hibiscus, ti leaf and Kona coffee. Six locations on Maui: Piilani Village Shopping Center, Front Street, The Shops at Wailea, Whalers Village, Lahaina Cannery Mall and The Wharf Cinema Center.

Title: Crazy Shirts - Kauai
Content:
Famous for original quality t-shirt designs for over 50 years, Crazy Shirts casual apparel has modern styling from head to toe for men, women and children. Its unique and innovative specialty-dyed shirts  incorporate the real thing: Kona coffee beans, hibiscus, lavender, cranberry, coconut, and now, tangerine! Inspired by California orange groves, it’s the perfect summertime color—bold and tangy like a burst of sunshine. Tees are dyed in real tangerine juice and other citrus ingredients.

Also see their selection of polo, pima cotton and long-sleeved shirts, shorts, swimwear, jackets, dresses and accessories.

Four locations on Kaua; Poipu Shopping Village, Anchor Cove Shopping Center, Old Koloa Town, Coconut Marketplace and Poipu Shopping Village. Stores hours vary.

Title: Crazy Shirts - Oahu
Content:
Famous for original quality t-shirt designs for over 50 years, Crazy Shirts casual wear features contemporary stylings for the entire family. An innovative approach to dyeing incorporates natural island and unusual elements such as hibiscus, ti leaf, Kona coffee, lavender, cranberry, coconut, and the newest, tangerine!

Inspired by California orange groves, it’s the perfect summertime color—bold and tangy like a burst of sunshine. Tees are dyed in real tangerine juice and other citrus ingredients.

Also check out their polo, pima cotton and long-sleeve shirts, shorts, swimwear, jackets and accessories.

Shops at Ala Moana Center, Hyatt Regency Waikiki, International Market Place, Hilton Hawaiian Village, Waikiki Beach Walk, The MODERN Honolulu, Ward Centre, Pearlridge Center and Lau Hala Shops in Kailua.

Title: Discount Fabric Warehouse - Kauai
Content: If you have sewing skills or are a creative craftperson, then stop by Discount Fabric Warehouse for the widest selection of fabrics including Hawaiian prints, as well as quilt and craft supplies. Take advantage of warehouse direct prices and create a memento that will truly remind you of your Hawai'i vacation!

Title: Discount Fabric Warehouse - Big Island
Content:
The seamstress in you will come alive with the wide variety of fabrics and sewing accessories available at Discount Fabric Warehouse. It's a one-stop shop for all your sewing needs! Find all kinds of prints—Hawaiian, tropical, Asian, novelty and holiday and more—all at discount prices. No space in your luggage? They offer shipping for your convenience!

Also visit our Warehouse in Hilo... 933 Kanoelehua Ave.
Image Alt Text: Discount Fabric Warehouse - Big Island - Hawaii|

Title: Hilo Hattie - Oahu
Content: Founded in 1963, Hilo Hattie has grown from one store into a chain of five stores—on O‘ahu, Maui, Kaua‘i and in Kona, along with its online store at hilohattie.com—to become Hawai‘i’s largest retailer, manufacturer and wholesaler of Hawaiian fashions and gifts. “The Store of Hawai‘i” features a wonderful assortment of Hawaiian fashions, gifts, souvenirs, t-shirts, home and beach accessories, gourmet foods and stunning island jewelry. Don’t forget their island wear and gifts for the entire family.

Title: Hilo Hattie - Kauai
Content: One of the largest varieties of made-in-Hawaii items in one place. This is the world's largest manufacturer of Hawaiian and resort wear with sizes, styles and prints for the entire family. Title: Hilo Hattie - Maui
Content: When you think of contemporary Hawaiian apparel and resortwear, Hilo Hattie is a natural fit. In addition to the aloha shirt that will take you from day to night, The Store of Hawaii continues to create stylish wear for every member of the family. You'll also find gift items such as island edibles, bath and body products, home decor and jewelry.

Title: West Loch Golf Course
Content: West Loch Golf Course is a short but challenging layout which incorporates a variety of water features. Located in Leeward Oahu, approximately 45 minutes from Waikiki. West Loch is a City of Honolulu municipal course.

Title: Leilehua Golf Course
Content:
Leilehua Golf Course is an 18-hole golf course nestled between Wheeler Army Airfield and Mililani Tech Park. With a sweeping view of the mountains, the course offers a driving range, practice facility, pro shop and full-service restaurant and snack bar.

It is a military golf course that opened in 1945 and is open to the public. Designed by U.S. Army Engineers, Leilehua Golf Course measures 7019 yards from the longest tees and has a slope rating of 129 and a 73.9 USGA rating.

Title: Moanalua Golf Club
Content: In 1898 Samuel M. Damon constructed an 18-hole course on his vast estate at Moanalua in the year of Annexation of the Hawaiian Islands by the United States, just a little over a decade after golf was introduced in America.  Soon after Moanalua Golf Course was shortened to nine holes in 1901. Moanalua Golf Club measures 2972 yards from the longest tees and has a slope rating of 117 and a 33.9 USGA rating. The course features 2 sets of tees for different skill levels. Greens and fairways are bermuda grass.

Title: Pali Golf Course
Content: A picturesque and challenging course located on the Windward side of Oahu along the foothills of the Koolau mountain range. Scenic views of the mountains and Kaneohe Bay. City of Honolulu municipal course.

Title: Ewa Villages Golf Course
Content: Challenging links style layout with wind playing a critical factor in how difficult the course plays. Relatively tight fairways. Located in Leeward Oahu it is an approximately 45 minute drive from Waikiki hotels. City of Honolulu municipal course.

Title: Ted Makalena Golf Course
Content: The 18-hole Ted Makalena Golf Course in Waipahu, HI is a public golf course that opened in 1971. Ted Makalena Golf Course measures 5976 yards from the longest tees and has a slope rating of 110 and a 67.9 USGA rating. Ted Makalena is a City of Honolulu municipal course.

Title: Hawaii Country Club
Content: Hawaii Country Club is the oldest public golf course on Oahu. Opened in 1957, this 5,916 yard, 18-hole golf course offers unparalleled views of the Koolau Mountains, Pearl Harbor and Diamond Head. Monkeypod trees and hills abound, making this course a challenge to play, but still a perfect place for beginners. In addition to being good for beginners, rates are relatively low. The course is not in the best condition compared to other Oahu courses.

Title: Ala Wai Golf Course
Content: Flat and sporty course lcoated on the edge of Waikiki on the Ala Wai Canal. Views of Diamond Head, the Koolau Mountains and the Waikiki skyline. A city of Honolulu municipal course.

Title: Waikele Country Club
Content: From every hole of Waikele Country Club, players encounter beautiful vistas, strategically placed bunkers, ponds and waterfalls.  The public course overlooks Pearl Harbor and the blue Pacific. Turn, and your gaze sweeps from Diamond Head to the sculpted slopes of the Ko’olau and Waianae mountains.

Title: Turtle Bay Golf - Fazio
Content: The George Fazio Course at Turtle Bay Resort opened in 1972. The 18-hole design meanders among traditional Hawaiian palms while skirting the North Shore coast on numerous occasions. It is known for generally being more forgiving than the Arnold Palmer Course and having breathtaking ocean views on both the back and front nine. It is a popular walking course because it can be played from a shorter distance and there are far fewer forced carries.

Title: Royal Kunia Country Club
Content: The course offers an uncompromising panoramic view of the entire south shore of Oahu. Spectacular views of Pearl Harbor, the Ko’olau and Waianae mountain ranges, the city of Honolulu and Diamond Head await every golf shot. The scenic, rolling fairways are lined with palm trees and other tropical native flora, along with six water features and 99 bunkers which adds to the aesthetic appeal of this picturesque golf course.

Title: Royal Hawaiian Country Club
Content: Opened in 1993, Royal Hawaiian Golf Club was the first course co-designed by renowned architects Peter and Perry Dye and recently redesigned by golf hall-of-famer Greg Norman. Nestled between the majestic Mount Olomana and Ko'olau Mountains, this course is an awe-inspiring experience with Oahu's most stunning views.

Title: Pearl Country Club
Content: Pearl County Club on Oahu has 18 holes, par 72 and 6787 yards, designed by Akira Sato. One of the finest golf courses on Oahu, Pearl Country Club has been in operation since 1967. Graced with stately trees of many varieties this course challenges all golfers with its varied terrain. Located on the gentle slopes of the Koolau mountain range, Pearl Country Club overlooks Pearl Harbor, the Arizona Memorial, the USS Missouri, and the Waianae Mountain Range to the west.

Title: Olomana Golf Links
Content: The Olomana Golf links course was designed by architect Bob Baldock and first opened its doors in the late 1960's. It is an 18 hole, par 72 golf course boasting majestic views of the Ko'olau Mountain Range and Olomana Peak itself. The front nine is very open and will expose the golfer to the elements. The back nine winds its way through a large wooded forest. As golfers make their way over the finely manicured fairways, they will encounter an abundance of endangered wildlife and trees.

Title: Mililani Country Club
Content: Since opening in 1966, the par 72, 6,455-yard Mililani Golf Club has established itself as one of Hawaii's finest golf experiences. Nestled on a plateau, with the Waianae Mountains and the Ko'olau Mountains stretching away in the distance, Mililani Golf Club provides a "get away from it all" feeling of remoteness. The Bob Baldock design features Norfolk Pines, Eucalyptus trees, African Tulip trees, and lush tropical Hawaiian foliage, in bloom all year round.  And for those who want to hone their golf skills, Mililani Golf Club offers a driving range, chipping green, and two putting greens conveniently located near the clubhouse.

Title: Makaha Valley Country Club (East)
Content: Nestled in captivating lowlands, Makaha Valley Country Club provides half of the one-two punch in this beautiful tourist region. Adjacent to Makaha Golf Club (WEST), Makaha Valley was designed by William F. Bell, who designed the Torrey Pines South Course which hosted the 2008 U.S. Open. Accented by gorgeous vistas, Makaha Valley weaves along rolling terrain framed by dense trees, ferns and tropical plants. Presenting golfers with a variety of doglegs and elevation changes, the course builds to an entertaining climax on one of Hawaii’s most demanding closing holes.

Title: Kapolei Golf Club
Content: Amateur golfers will revel in following the footsteps of great champions such as Greg Norman and Annika Sorenstam at Kapolei Golf Club, which hosted the LPGA Tour’s Ladies “Hawaiian Open” from 1996 to 2001 and PGA Champions Tour “Pacific Links Championship” from 2012 to 2014.  Designed by architect Ted Robinson, best known for Sahalee Country Club, Kapolei Golf Club is highly regarded for its magnificent beauty, floral gardens and strategic golf holes. Meandering over 190 rolling acres of a former sugar cane plantation, Kapolei’s elevated greens, 80 bunkers and five lakes provide delightful tactical challenges.

Title: Bay View Golf Course
Content: Opened in 1963, Bay View Golf Course is an 18-hole public course in Kaneohe, HI. The course was designed by Jimmy Ukauka and measures 3,399 yards from the longest tees, and has a slope rating of 91 and a 56.9 USGA rating. The course features 4 sets of tees for different skill levels. The majority of holes are par 3s so this is an ideal course for beginners or golfers wanting to work on their short game. Bay View plays to a par 60.

Title: Hawaii Prince Golf Club
Content: Hawaii Prince Golf Club designed by Arnold Palmer and Ed Seay offers 27 dramatic holes, the only golf course of its kind in Hawaii. Three interchangeable nines create a variety of playing conditions for all skill levels. Situated on Oahu’s sunny Ewa Plain, the course boasts 270 acres of sheer beauty and offers stunning views of the rain-carved Waianae Mountains. Long verdant fairways are lined with numerous white sand bunkers and 10 strategically placed lakes.

Title: Hawaii Kai Golf Course
Content: Located just 13 miles east of Waikiki, Hawaii Kai Golf Course offers a Championship course featuring a challenging layout with elevation changes and skilled dogleg holes, with breathtaking views of Moloka`i in the distance. Whether you’re a beginning golfer, junior, or just wanting to hone your iron and short game skills, our Robert Trent Jones-designed, 18-hole Executive Par 3 Course is a fun and casual setting with views overlooking Oahu’s east shore and renowned Sandy Beach Park.

Title: Ewa Beach Golf Club
Content: Opened in 1992, this Robin Nelson-designed championship golf course features rolling greens and lush fairways. The golf course design has features that are reminiscent of a traditional links-style layout, designed to take you away from the clubhouse on the front nine and return to the clubhouse on the inward nine. It is truly a unique and challenging layout for all playing abilities.

Title: Coral Creek Golf Club
Content:
Coral Creek offers rounds that are both challenging and demanding, yet is usually fair and enjoyable. It is widely regarded as a true and comprehensive test of ones golfing skills at any handicap level.

Coral Creek was designed by Robin Nelson and opened in 1999. Coral Creek was the first course in the state to utilize luxuriously durable and verdantly stunning Seashore Paspalum grass throughout the layout. The par 72 layout measures 6,808 yards from the back tees.

Title: Ko Olina Golf
Content: Ko Olina Golf Club, one of Golf Digest's "Top 75 Resort Courses in the U.S.," is a challenging 18-hole course built in 1990 by renowned golf course architect Ted Robinson. Typical of his designs, Ko Olina Golf Club features exceptional water features, multi-tiered greens, large landing areas, and a moderate length which makes it perfect for beginners and experts alike.

Title: Turtle Bay Golf - Palmer
Content:
Opening in 1992, the Arnold Palmer Course, designed by Arnold Palmer and Ed Seay, was rated one of Golf Magazine’s “Top 10 New Courses” in America and ranked 4th among Golf Digest’s “Best New Resort Courses in America” the year it opened. The Palmer-Seay layout features two very distinct experiences.

The front nine will challenge golfers with a Scottish Links style layout, while the back nine has a more tropical setting as it meanders through a tropical jungle and forest of ironwoods. The course forms a horseshoe around the Punaho’olapa marsh, an unspoiled 100-acre wetlands and bird sanctuary. Water comes into play on 14 of the Palmer holes. The 17th, the signature hole offers panoramic Pacific ocean views from the green while the hole is dotted with nine bunkers, which makes it as challenging as it is scenic.

Title: Waikaloa Kings’ Course
Content: Self-described as a “player’s course”, this Scottish links style layout can stretch to over 7,000 yards from the tips. Lakes, lava outcroppings, and pot bunkers supply the complexity at this Tom Weiskopf and Jay Morrish designed public course.

Title: Waikaloa Beach Course
Content: This Robert Trent Jones, Jr. design opened in 1981. The public course is generous from the front tees and challenging from the back (6,566 yards). The course offers amazing views and the signature par 5 7<sup>th</sup> opens with the Pacific directly in front of you and lava fields bordering the fairways left and right.

Title: Mauna Lani Golf Courses
Content:
The Mauna Lani Golf Course complex consists of two championship layouts, the North and South Courses, and one nine hole short course.

The North Course is characterized by rolling terrain punctuated by Kiawe (mesquite) forests. The par 72 layout plays to 6,913 yards from the championship tees, and 5,307 yards from the forward tees.

Title: Mauna Kea Golf Course
Content: Designed by Robert Trent Jones, Sr. Mauna Kea was the first 18 hole golf course to open on the Big Island in 1964. On what was once a barren lava field, fairways tumble across seaside cliffs with unfolding ocean and coastal views.

Title: Haulalai Golf Course
Content: This Jack Nicklaus designed championship course is only open to Four Seasons guests. The 7,100 yard test begins in a lush oasis, then flows across bright green fairways contoured against black lava, then returns to the ocean for the final holes.

Title: Hilo Municipal Golf Course
Content: Opened in 1951 Hilo Golf Course is the only municipal course on the island. Plays to a par 71, 6,326 yards from the back tees. The course plays in consistently wet conditions and there are no sand traps. $44 for 18 holes, 7 days a week.

Title: Hapuna Golf Course
Content: Part of the Westin Hapuna Beach Resort, this Arnold Palmer/Ed Seay designed 18 hole, par 72 course begins at sea level and rises 700 feet in elevation. Lush greens set amidst a dark lava field, with views of the Pacific on every hole. Men’s tees range from 6,029-6,875 yards in length. Women’s tees at 5,067 yards.

Title: Hamakua Country Club
Content: Founded in 1926 by Scottish engineers employed at the local sugar plantation, Hamakua is the  second oldest golf course on the island. The nine-hole layout plays to a 4,800 yard par 66 when played twice from the two sets of tees. Located at 1,200 feet above sea level on the rural northeast coast, Hamakua offers a cultural as much as a golf experience. $20 gives you unlimited golf all day, and the “honor” system is in play- put your money in the slot if no one’s around!

Title: Maui Nui
Content: Half of all visitors to Maui snorkel while on their vacation. Before you put on your mask and fins to explore our local coral reefs, please take a minute to become familiar with important steps you should take to protect these beautiful and fragile ecosystems.  While coral reefs worldwide have become threatened by climate change, sediment runoff, and pollution from fertilizers and chemicals, the choices that visitors make when they’re visiting Maui significantly impact the health of our reefs,” says Maui Nui Marine Resource Council Chair and Co-Founder Robin Newbold.  “As a visitor to Maui, your choices make a huge difference to our coral reefs,” says Newbold. “There are simple yet vital things visitors can do, or actually not do, to preserve this precious resource.” Maui Nui Marine Resource Council asks all who swim, surf, snorkel or dive in the ocean to avoid using sunscreens containing oxybenzone and octinoxate, two chemicals that are illegal in Hawaii because they harm and kill corals. Additional chemicals to avoid are avobenzone and octocrylene. Choose zinc based sunscreen instead or cover up with a rash guard, hat and swim tights to minimize your sun exposure. Learn more at www.mauireefs.org/sunscreen.  Second, avoid stepping or walking on coral. Doing so will harm the tiny soft-bodied animals called polyps that slowly build up the reef structure. Scraping against coral can cause serious infection as well. The team at Maui Nui Marine Resource Council recommends that you use a flotation device to help you keep your fins up and away from coral. If you must stand, stand only on sand, never on coral.  Always give sea turtles at least 10 feet of space, in the water and on land. If you see a Hawaiian monk seal resting on shore, do not approach – and keep children and pets away – to protect these critically endangered marine mammals.   Maui Nui Marine Resources Council is a 501(c)3 nonprofit founded in 2007 whose mission is to “preserve, protect and enhance the coral reefs of Maui Nui”. For more information on how you can be a responsible guest visit mauireefs.org/snorkel.

Title: Bill Wyland
Content:
When Bill Wyland formulated the successful strategy for his namesake gallery on Front Street in Lahaina, it started with his personal favorite artists.

“I’ve been in the art gallery business since 1988,” he says. “I opened up a gallery in Haleiwa on the north shore of Oahu showcasing my brother Wyland’s work. The business grew fast. At one point, I had 17 galleries on the islands. I know art- and I know great artists!”

After selling the galleries, the former Air Force fireman and professional skier retired from the gallery business and moved on to other ventures. Bill still owns a fuel business and virus testing equipment company, and runs an angel investment firm. But in 2016 Bill was drawn back to his first business love, and it resulted in Bill Wyland Galleries in Lahaina, the largest in the state.

“What I love about this gallery is that it’s comprised of my favorite artists. I still live on Oahu, but I spend a lot of time here because I enjoy sharing our collection with guests from around the world.”

Artists whose works are displayed at the gallery include:

Ruben Aira, Jr., Jeff Albrecht, Arozi, Michael Godard, Henry Asencio, Andrea Everhart, Marti Dogs, Josh Saraffin, Chris Gutzeit, Wade Jackson, Scott Hanson, Dennis Matthewson, Shannon McDonald, LeoHone, David Miller, Bryan Pezman, John Pitre, Jeffrey Robert, Andre Romasukov, and The Twins.

“Every artist in our gallery is internationally known. We’re blessed to represent some of the top names in the world of art.”

Make the Bill Wyland Galleries a must stop when you visit the former whaling village of Lahaina. And if you see him, say aloha.

For more information on the gallery and the artists, go to billwylandgalleries.com.

Title: Maui Nalu
Content:
Owner Chuck has been offering great souvenirs on Maui for over 27 years. Now, he’s starting his own brand. 

When Chuck opened his very first store, Awesome Tee’s, in Kihei, he soon realized that the “Tee’s” after the “Awesome” brought in people looking for golf tees - instead of T-shirts. He moved his business to the west side of the island and opened Logowear Maui in Lahaina, with Maui Resortwear following five years later.

“I opened ‘Maui Nalu’ in Queen Kaahumanu Center in September of last year to be the spring board for our new, Maui Nalu brand of high quality aloha shirts, T-shirts and board shorts,” he says.

In addition to bringing the Maui Nalu brand to life, the store offers quality Hawaiian lifestyle merchandise that appeals to visitors and locals alike. “We carry Reyn Spooner and Tori Richard as well and a fabulous selection of women’s and children’s wear.”

The desire to build his own clothing brand which had been stirring around in his head all these years has finally come together for the native New Yorker. “So far we have the logo and we’re working on several Aloha and T-shirts designs,” he says. 

 Chuck is an avid windsurfer who moved to Maui from Long Island “because I wanted to be someplace where I could be in the water twelve months a year- without a wetsuit! Now I’m launching a clothing brand that I, all my windsurfing friends and everyone else will feel great wearing when they’re both in and out of the water.”

Visit Maui Nalu, Maui Resortwear and Logowear Maui and you’ll check all the boxes off your souvenir list.

Title: Lineage
Content:
What do the prestigious James Beard Foundation Award, television’s Top Chef and Hawai‘i’s ubiquitous ABC Stores all have in common? Sheldon Simeon, Executive Chef of the hot new restaurant LINEAGE in Wailea, Maui. Chef Sheldon, as he is known, was twice voted “Fan Favorite” during two separate appearances on the Bravo Network’s Top Chef. He opened LINEAGE in October 2018 in partnership with venerable ABC Stores and was nominated as a semi-finalist by the James Beard Foundation for Best New Restaurant in March. The James Beard Awards are akin to the Oscars for movies, so being named a semi-finalist is a prestigious honor.

My wife and I, during a brief staycation recently, took the opportunity to dine at LINEAGE. The restaurant serves traditional local Hawai‘i fare in a unique way. Our delightful waiter Jordan got us started with a cocktail, a Mai’a Tai (the unique spelling is intentional) and a “mocktail,” a Menko Madness. We instantly realized why LINEAGE recently won a Best Cocktail competition on Maui. The Mai’a Tai, a blend of Banks 5 Rum, banana milk punch, walnut, pecan, Giffard Apricot de Rousillon, lime and almond-spice liqueur was delicious. The Menko Madness, a house-made POG (passion fruit-orange-guava) juice, coconut cream, lemon-lime soda and egg white, was a Hawaiian liquid treat—not too sweet and delightful.

 The restaurant is a shared plate concept and the first food offerings to the table arrived via dim sum cart and Alexandra, who walked us through each of the dishes. We chose house-made pita style chips with a cream cheese dip topped with mild kim chee spice, pickled vegetables from local farms and a salmon dumpling that my wife wouldn’t let me get near. The chips and dip lasted the whole meal and the pickled vegetables were perfect for munching between bites when the other dishes arrived. Since both my wife and I are grazers, we were in heaven.

Jordan then walked us through the Snacks portion of the menu. We chose the Maui Flying Saucer after he informed us that locals waited 90 minutes in line at the Maui County Fair for them. OMG! I’ve been to a lot of county fairs where fried food reigns supreme, but the Flying Saucers came from somewhere in fried food heaven. It consists of two pieces of brioche bread enclosing homemade beef goulash and Tillamook Cheddar, and then fried. It was like the best grilled cheese we’ve ever had, except better, if that’s possible.

[Full disclosure: this was the only item that we ordered that was filling, so don’t go crazy on the Flying Saucers unless you want to end up staring at all the other food on your table.]

We countered the Flying Saucers with the Bottom of the Plate Lunch salad, which for locals, is self-explanatory. Picture everything left after you eat the meat at the top of a mixed plate—shaved cabbage, kalbi dressing, mac salad mayo and smoked beef fat—so Hawai‘i and so good.

 After much consulting with Jordan we picked two items off the Pupu Line—the Smoke Meat, a plate of sweet pork, guava jelly and piko onion and HRC-19, the local fresh catch of the day. In our case, it was Mahi Mahi served over Molokai sweet potato, upcountry carrots, macadamia nut and with a sugar cane buerre blanc sauce. I laugh thinking about the Smoke Meat, because at first my wife remarked that it might be her least favorite dish, but every time I looked up from my food she was putting more on her plate. By the end of the meal, it was gone and we laughed that it went from her least favorite to her most favorite. And, why not? The meat was a pork belly, or thick bacon, in a delicious sweet sauce topped with the sautéed pink onions. Ono! Words won’t describe the Mahi Mahi; just check out the photo. ‘Nuf said. While we were busy chowing down, General Manager Matt visited our table and brought a Charred Brocollini, compliments of the chef. I don’t know how he knew how much more I like brocollini than broccoli, but we appreciated it. Perfectly charred and served with a roof Yuzu vinaigrette, it was the perfect complement to the meat and fish. I was compelled to compliment Matt Godfrey on the service that Jordan and Alexandra provided and I could see him beam. “One thing we learned from ABC was the philosophy of treating employees like ‘ohana (family),” said Matt. “Instead of the typical restaurant philosophy of using part-time workers, we offer full-time hours and benefits.” The desserts—a lilikoi sorbet and the Filipino Cereal—were amazing. The sorbet was so tangy that it exploded on the taste buds. It was the perfect complement to the other, which was an adventurous blend of pannacotta on the bottom, fresh avocados, homemade cookies topped with a poured over sweet cream. The only thing more sublime than how it tasted was the story Jordan shared: “Chef Sheldon grew up in a large Filipino family that ate traditional food for breakfast, like Spam musubi and such. One day his grandfather found him the kitchen mixing crackers, sugar and cinnamon. When he asked him what he was doing, Sheldon told him that he had been introduced to cereal at a neighbor’s house. He was trying to make his own cereal!”

We left LINEAGE feeling like we had a uniquely Hawaiian dining experience and a few new friends to boot. Don’t visit Maui without planning a meal there. If you don’t trust me, trust James Beard.

Happy hour from 5:00PM-6:00PM.

Title: Miso Phat Sushi
Content: Miso Phat is a family owned and operated sushi bar in Kihei, with a second location in Kahana. The owners of Miso Phat operate their own boat, Shiso Phat (get it?) that provides fresh fish to the restaurant. No reservations- first come, first served.

Title: Cuatro Restaurant
Content: Cuatro is a restaurant that bills itself as "for everyone". Guests are welcome from the beach or the hotel room. Cuatro was voted "Best New Restaurant on Maui" by the Maui News in 2009. Owner/Chef Eric Arbogast is a veteran of several popular Maui kitchens. His menu mingles Latin and Pacific Rim fare.

Title: Buzz's Original Steakhouse
Content:
Buzz's has been a great beach hangout in Kailua since 1962. It's an open-air restaurant that sits right across from Kailua Beach Park and is the nearest eatery to the Lanikai Beach community, making it popular with visitora and locals. Many reviewers speak highly of the cocktails. The food is good, but this guy, who''s eaten there several times, thinks the ambiance of the place is king.

A little presidential history: when Barack Obama was President, and vacationed in Kailua at Christmastime each year, he and his family would dine at Buzz's on the last night of his vacation each year. It became a local game to see if you could make a reservation on the same night that he ate there, which was of course a well guarded secret. If you were in the restaurant when the Secret Service secured the restaurant about 40 minutes prior to his arrival, you could stay- and dine with the President of the United States. I was one night off the year I tried to time it.

Title: Leonard's Bakery
Content: Since 1946, Leonard's Bakery has been serving up malasadas - a Portuguese pastry (think donut without a hole) - to visitors and locals alike. Leonard's is an institution on the island. Lines can be long, partially because every order comes fresh out of the oven. They're best eaten on the spot. Located near Waikiki on Kapahulu Avenue.

Title: Shark's Cove
Content:
If you're looking for a nice cove to spend your day here in Oahu, make sure to check out Sharks Cove. This natural beauty is located on Oahu's North Shore in Pupukea Beach Park and has tons of stunning marine life to sight-see and great waters for swimming. Yes... you read that right. Swimming in sharks cove.

Are there Sharks in Sharks Cove?

While sharks cove is connected to the ocean and there is always a possibility of sharks, it is very unlikely that this will be the case when you visit. Now we know that the name may seem a little daunting, but you'll be happy to know that the cave didn't get its name from being home to a ton of sharks.

Why Is Sharks Cove Called Sharks Cove?

Since Sharks Cove isn't named after the marine life that inhabits it, where did the name come from? Well, the name "Sharks Cove" is in relationship with the shape of the cove when seen from the skies. The shape of the cove looks a lot like a shark when viewed from above. Cool, right? Make sure if you plan a visit here that you enjoy the sun for us and take a dip in the cove for good measure. Also... bring a camera while you explore the area. If not, don't worry. Either way, you are sure to remember your Shark's Cove adventures!

Title: Koko Head Stairs Hike
Content:
The Koko Head Stairs hike is a popular one for both visitors and locals. Be forewarned, you need to be in good physical condition to complete this hike. While slightly less than three quarters of a mile in length, it is almost a 1,000 foot climb. There is one foot of elevation change for every two feet of distance.

The path is comprised of 1,048 railway stairs, and approximately a third of the way up there is a railway bridge that can be disconcerting to those afraid of heights. You have to carefully navigate the railroad ties while seeing a 20-30 foot drop between the ties. Some people circumnavigate the bridge on a path to the right.

The reward for making it to the summit is a breathtaking view of Hanauma Bay, Hawaii Kai and ocean views all the way to Molokai and Maui. Be careful going down, more injuries occur from people twisting an ankle or falling on the way down. There is at least one helicopter rescue per week, and that ride is scarier than the hike. Injured hikers are put into a basket that is attached by rope to the helicopter. Injured hikers are dangling from a rope as the helicopter delivers them to the grass of the regional park below. We've seen more than one rescue. It looks terrifying.

Wear breathable clothes and shoes that grip.

During WWII, the military built several bunkers at the summit of Koko Head Crater. They also built a railway to move supplies and personnel up and down. The railway ties that remain today comprise the stairs of the Koko Head hike.

Title: Experience Nutridge
Content: Experience Nutridge Luau bills themselves as "no big production!". That's because they're an intimate, limited guest production sharing Hawaiian culture. Arrive as guests, leave as family. The historical luau site offers incredible views of the Honolulu skyline. Open Monday-Friday.

Title: Bogart's Cafe
Content: In 2000, new owner Maria Barnette converted an ice cream and shave ice parlor into a breakfast cafe. Today it serves breakfast, lunch and dinner. Popular for its acai bowls. Located just outside Waikiki near Queen Kapiolani Park.

Title: Zippy's
Content: Zippy's grew from simple beginnings in 1966, when brothers Francis and Charles Higa started their first restaurant on King Street in Honolulu. Zippy's has become a Hawaiian institution, with 24 locations on the islands. Check website for locations and phone numbers.

Title: Doraku Sushi
Content: Doraku is the creation of Kevin Aoki, son of legendary restaurateur Rocky Aoki, who brought Benihana of Tokyo to the world. Doraku brings together influences outside tradtional Japanese to their sushi and Izakaya craft, i.e. their Ahi Nachos, that come Poke style with Beg-eye tuna.

Title: Restaurant Suntory Honolulu
Content: Restaurant Suntory offers authentic Japanese dishes, from shabu-shabu to sushi, teppanyaki and elegant Kaiseki dinners. They offer both teppanyaki grill dining and Washoku dining (traditional Japanese cuisine).

Title: Moku Kitchen
Content: Moku Kitchen, located in the SALT complex in Kakaako, bills itself as a "chef-driven concept that brings Hawaii's rich upcountry farming and ranching heritage to downtown Honolulu's urban lifestyle". Call for reservations or most up-to-date hours of operation.

Title: Cinnamon's Restaurant
Content: Of all the popular breakfast spots in Kailua, Cinnamon's might land at the top. Popular for their pancakes since 1985, they offer up some local spins such as their guava chiffon pancakes. Open 8-2 Monday-Friday and 7-2 Saturday and Sunday.

Title: Monkeypod Kitchen
Content: Owned by Hawaii culinary Chef Peter Merriman, Monkeypod serves up classic cuisine with Hawaiian influences. Centrally located across the street from several large Ko Olina resorts, reservations are recommended as the restaurant often has a wait.

Title: Nico's Kailua
Content: Nico's Kailua location opened in 2017 following the success of Nico's Pier 38. It's a casual eatery where you order your food at the counter and they bring it to your table. Same great, fresh seafood as the original. They have some killer desserts.

Title: Nico's Pier 38
Content: Open for breakfast and lunch, Nico's Pier 38 is located steps away from the Honolulu Fish Market, where fresh catches are auctioned off each day. Two of Nico's three founders were commercial fishermen. Nico's has delivered consistent, quality seafood dishes since 2004.

Title: Aloha Kitchen

Title: Teddy's Bigger Burgers
Content: Teddy's opened its first location in 1998 and has grown to include stores on Maui and in Washington and Iowa. The burgers are hand-crafted daily and charbroiled to order, so it takes a little longer to get your food than most fast food places. Teddy's have a 50's burger joint feel to them, with a simple menu of burgers, fries and shakes.

Title: Restaurant 604
Content: Restaurant 604 offers open-air, waterfront dining at Pearl Harbor. It's conveniently located next to the USS Arizona Memorial. It's a good spot to eat before or after your tour. Good food, great atmosphere at reasonable prices. Very popular, so expect to wait if you don't have reservations.

Title: Michel's at the Colony Surf
Content: Michel's at the Colony Surf has been a Hawaiian fine dining staple since 1962. It is one of the few restaurants to still offer tableside dishes, including the lobster bisque with fresh Maine lobster flamed in cognac, and their signature dessert, the Hawaiian apple banana flambé finished with dark rum.

Title: Arancino
Content: Voted "Best Italian Restaurant in Hawaii" by Honolulu Magazine and the Honolulu Star-Advertiser, Arancino showcases classic Italian dishes with a modern twist using only the finest ingredients imported from Italy. There are three locations: one at the Kahala Hotel and Resort and one at 255 Beach Walk in Waikiki in addition to the address below.

Title: Beachhouse at the Moana

Title: Livestock Tavern
Content: Livestock Tavern is a self-described "seasonal, American eatery" that changes its menu regularly while sticking to its focus on comfort foods. In 2019 Livestock was awarded the Best Lunch Critic's Choice Award by the Star-Advertiser, Honolulu's daily newspaper. Great place to eat on a Friday or Saturday night before bar-hopping on Hotel Street.

Title: Artizen by MW
Content: Nominated by the James Beard Foundation as Best New Restaurant in 2014, this restaurant is known as much by its dessert as its fine dining. Restaurant co-owner Michell Karr-Ueoka has been nominated more than once for the Janes Beard Best Pastry Chef. In their new location in the Velocity Building, they serve breakfast, lunch and dinner.

Title: Helena's Hawaiian Food
Content: If you're looking at authentic, local Hawaiian food at great prices, look no further than Helena's. Since 1946, Helena's has been serving up poi, lau lau and short ribs to generations of loyal customers. In 2000, Helena's received the prestigious Regional Classic Award from the James Beard Foundation. Helena's is only open Tuesday-Friday so plan accordingly.

Title: Hula Grill
Content: Located just upstairs from its famous sister restaurant, Duke's Waikiki, Hula Grill claims its inspiration from "local fisherman, farmers and ohana". Open for breakfast lunch and dinner. Been there, food's very good!

Title: Tommy Bahama
Content: The most talked about feature of Tommy Bahama is the open air rooftop, complete with sand, fire pit, live music and a stunning view of Waikiki. Our experience is that the food is good, and reviews left on other sites agree. Try the pineapple crème brûlée if it's available.

Title: Kalapawai Cafe and Deli
Content: The Kalapawai Cafe and Deli opened in 2006 as an extension of the original, iconic Kalapawai Market that has sat at the entrance to Kailua Beach Park since 1932. The market is a landmark and a favorite subject for local artists. The food at the deli is inspired by "home cooked meals, backyard bbqs and beachside picnics". You can sit down in the cafe or just pick up coffee and pastries. At night, it has the feel of a more upscale place than during the day and it has some outdoor seating as well. Nice little Kailua spot.

Title: Haleiwa Joe's
Content: Haleiwa Joe's is one of those "institutions" on the island- a regular stop for locals and frequent visitors alike. The second location in Kaneohe opened in 2000. It's an open air restaurant in a lush valley overlooking its own tropical garden and koi pond. The original location overlooks the Haleiwa Boat Harbor. The food menu features fresh catches, locally grown produce and quality steaks. Check the website for the Haleiwa address.

Title: Karai Crab
Content: Karai Crab, which means "spicy crab", opened in 2012 and consistently gets good reviews from customers. It can be described as "local-style seafood that has a fun and spicy menu" that includes locally sourced ingredients. (The people that refer to it as "local style" may never have been to New Orleans.)

Title: Chef Chai
Content: Known for his mastery of blending flavors, Chef Chai Chaowasaree has been a staple of the fine dining scene in Honolulu for many years, and is noted for creating dishes like Fresh Ahi Katsu with Tomato Mango Salsa Wasabi Curry Sauce. The restaurant has been recommended by such international magazines as Bon Appetit, Travel & Leisure and Gourmet.

Title: Roy's
Content: Roy's is a tale of local chef made good. Born in Tokyo, Chef Roy Yamaguchi had his first taste of seafood while visiting his grandparents on Maui. His numerous accolades include the prestigious James Beard Awards. There are three Roy's on Oahu. The Waikiki address is listed below. Check the website for the addresses for their Hawaii Kai and Ko Olina locations.

Title: Haleiwa Beach House
Content: Haleiwa Beach House opened its doors in 2016 in the extensively renovated Jameson's by the Sea building. It's been one of the top rated restaurants on review sites. Their fairly extensive menu includes Hawaiian favorites like mahi mahi, Kalua pork and loco moco. Nice views of the harbor.

Title: Little Village Noodle House
Content: For 20 years Little Village Noodle House has been serving up quality Chinese cuisine in the heart of Chinatown. This is a staple for locals living "town side" who enjoy the Northern Chinese approach to cooking, which emphasizes bold flavors and stellar sauces over thick gravies. This Week staff has eaten at Little Village many times and can vouch for the food quality and value. There are a small number of free parking spots behind the restaurant.

Title: Mahina and Sun's
Content: Mahina and Sun's, located in the Surfjack Hotel, features unique takes on island cuisine in a hip, casual atmosphere. The restaurant is the fourth for local chef Ed Kenney. Guests we've talked to love the feel of the Surfjack and the restaurant gets overall high marks.

Title: 53 By the Sea
Content: From the moment you arrive at 53 By the Sea you know you're in for an elegant, high-end dining experience. The restaurant itself has the look of a mansion. The interior is beautiful and spacious. But the view of the Waikiki skyline and Diamond Head from across the water is spectacular. Best known for its seafood, 53 is pricey but gets consistently good reviews.

Title: Duke's Waikiki
Content: Duke's is the signature restaurant in the highly successful TS Restaurants portfolio. (One of their eateries, Hula Grill, is located upstairs from Duke's.) Duke's is popular for a variety of reasons: on the beach location with great views and ambiance chief among them. Locals love it for their great bar with live entertainment and the signature Duke's Mai Tai. It's one of a handlful of Waikiki restaurants that locals will frequent. Duke's is one of the most iconic restaurants in Hawaii.

Title: Marukame Udon
Content: For years, Marukame Udon has been known for two things- long lines snaking down the sidewalk from their Kuhio Avenue entryway (the line moves fast, by the way) and for being one of the best dining values in Waikiki. Most people feel it's well worth the wait. A must eat for noodle lovers and budget diners.

Title: The Pig and the Lady
Content: The Pig and the Lady is well known to locals, as much for its participation in many farmer's markets around the island as its popular Chinatown restaurant. And like a lot of Chinatown restaurants, it's popular with locals- always a good sign. They're reputed to have some of the best Vietnamese food on Oahu.

Title: Side Street Inn
Content: Side Street Inn is popular with locals, who love their huge, family-style portions and local-style menu. Bookending Waikiki on Kapahulu Avenue and adjacent to the Ala Moana Center on Hopaka (the "side street" ), Side Street is casual, fun, loud and filling. Expect leftovers and a reasonable bill at the end. The Kapahulu restaurant is located 614 Kapahulu Avenue.

Title: Hy's Steakhouse
Content: For over 40 years, Hy's has earned its reputation as the best classic steakhouse on Oahu. This is probably the number one special occasion restaurant for Oahu residents- even if they do have to come to Waikiki! Elegant, old-style surroundings, five-star service and USDA prime and aged beef take you back to a fine dining experience from yesteryear. The food is classic too- Caesar Salad and Warm Spinach Salad prepared at your table while steaks are cooked in full view over fragrant Hawaiian Kiawe wood. If you eat here, it might be your favorite meal.

Title: Cafe Kaila
Content: After its quiet opening in 2007, this Market City Shopping Center eatery quickly became of the most popular breakfast spots on the island. Frequented by locals and visitors, expect to wait for a table. You'll find out soon enough why you waited.

Title: 12th Ave. Grill
Content: 12th Ave. Grill is an award-winning gem of a restaurant located in the heart of Kaimuki. Rustic, modern American cooking using ingredients from local Hawaiian farms and ranches. The daughter of one of our staff members worked there for a short time and raved about the food- a real compliment when it comes from a server.

Title: Yard House
Content: Hawaii loves its chain restaurants. Yard House is one of the fastest growing chain restaurants in the United States. It's easy to see why they've become so popular. Yard House is an upscale-casual eatery known for its large menu, food made from scratch daily, classic rock music and 130 taps of beer, ales and lagers. We wouldn't be surprised if the Waikiki Yard House is among its busiest- it's packed all the time.

Title: Tonkatsu Ginza Bairin
Content: This little restaurant, tucked into the Diamond Head side of Beach Walk, is a great find for those looking for genuine Tonkatsu (breaded pork cutlets). Ginza Bairin is a Ginza, Tokyo based specialty restaurant whose roots go back to 1927. The founder, Mr. Nobukatsu Shibuya, created a Tonkatsu sauce that is considered the gold standard.

Title: Highway Inn
Content: Part of the SALT complex in Kakaako, this second Highway Inn location opened in 2013. The family has been satisfying the appetites of Oahu families with their Hawaiian-style comfort food for over 70 years and three generations. Fish tacos and Kalua pork dishes are extremely popular, but this guy also recommends the Hawaiian beef stew.

Title: Uncle Bo's Pupu Bar & Grill
Content: Uncle Bo's on Kapahulu Avenue just outside Waikiki has been popular with locals and visitors for 15 years. They're known for their large, eclectic menu and generous portions. As of April, 2021 the menu had temporarily been pared down so check their website for current selection. They also have a newer Haleiwa location.

Title: M.A.C. 24/7 Waikiki
Content: M.A.C. 24/7 Waikiki Restaurant + Bar’s Modern American Cuisine is a long-time Waikiki favorite of locals and travelers alike. It’s best known as a place to satisfy your cravings day & night, with breakfast, lunch & dinner served from 6:00 am to 12 midnight in a contemporary diner atmosphere. M.A.C.’s award-winning menu features American & local favorites with a gourmet twist, prepared with local ingredients whenever possible.  The restaurant received international acclaim when their world-famous 5 lb. M.A.C. Daddy Pancakes were featured on Travel Channel’s Man Vs. Food. M.A.C. 24/7 was also recently voted Best Late-Night Eats - Best of Honolulu (Honolulu Magazine), People’s Choice Best Breakfast 2018-2019 (Honolulu Star Advertiser), Best Late Night Find - 2019 OpenTable Diner's Choice, and Best Restaurants for Brunch" 2018 OpenTable Diner's Choice.

Title: Waimea Blue Gallery
Content: Make time to browse the amazing art and photography at Waimea Blue Gallery.  Owner Akima Kai wants you to “feel the raw and wild power of the Earth” when you enter the studio. In addition to collections from several local artists, you’ll peruse Kai’s own nature photography, much of it shot in local waters while free diving. Waimea Blue has a stunning collection of surfboards that ride walls instead of waves. Made from individually selected pieces of local, exotic wood, each work is hand-shaped and sanded. Layers of resins are then applied to create one-of-a-kind Hawaiian art treasures. “We have surfboards as small as 21 inches high and as large as five and a half feet,” says Kai.

Title: Maui Snorkeling
Content:
Since 1985, Maui Snorkeling has run thousands of Maui Molokini Snorkel Tours, hundreds of Private Boat Charters, watched tens of thousands of Humpback whales during their annual migrations, and has provided the opportunity for people to swim with the most peaceful and beautiful Sea Turtles that Maui has to offer.

We've carried close to 1 million passengers, served families, honeymooners, senior citizens, young children, military personnel, and vacationers from every country on the globe. The original Lani Kai was retired in March 2020 and we welcomed Lani Kai II in August of 2020. Lani Kai II is a 53-foot state-of-the-art vessel that can accommodate up to 72 people on private boat charters and 50 people on public snorkeling tours. Our whale watching, snorkeling, and SCUBA diving tours leave out of Ma’alaea Harbor and travel to Molokini Crater, Turtle Town and Coral Gardens.

Since her launch in August, 2020, Lani Kai II has hosted major Hollywood productions, professional athletes and celebrities, and thousands of Maui visitors. We are committed to protecting our marine life and celebrating the beauty of Hawai’i!

Whether you are two honeymooners looking for a calm and relaxing snorkeling experience, or a couple celebrating 25 years of marriage, or a young family hoping for an unforgettable experience, Maui Snorkeling is definitely one of the top things to do in Maui and Molokini. We are happy to provide the best all inclusive packages Maui that includes morning snorkeling tour, afternoon snorkeling tour, and group & private charters.

CALL TODAY:  Toll-Free 888-983-8080

Title: Fly Shuttle Tours
Content:
If touring the coastline of Oahu in luxury, while sampling some of the island’s best cuisine sounds like a great way to spend a day, then look no further than Fly Shuttle & Tour’s “Beauty and the Feast Tour”.

“Our most popular tour allows guests to take in the spectacular coastline and mountains of Oahu,” says President Ty Lai. “In the course of one day, you’ll witness the awesome views of Hanauma Bay and Na Pali Lookouts, stroll the charming North Shore village of Haleiwa Town, and visit the most famous surfing beaches in the world.”

The day starts with a view of Hanauma Bay while savoring Leonard’s Malasadas, who has been serving their Portuguese “donuts without a hole” since 1953. Lunch is served from the North Shore Shrimp Truck, where guests choose between their butter garlic, spicy garlic lemon or coconut options.

Delicious snacking options continue at visits to Tropical Macadamia Nut Farm, Kahuku Fruit Stand and Dole Plantation. “No one ever steps off our luxury vans hungry,” says Lai.

In addition to the “ono” food stops, guests stretch their legs in historic Haleiwa Town, where they can stroll and shop in North Shore Marketplace and many other galleries and stores. All along the way, they are entertained and educated by Fly Shuttle’s five-star guides, riding in comfort aboard the best luxury fleet on the island.

The tour offers several pick-up and drop-off locations in Waikiki and Ko Olina.

In addition to this outstanding tour, Fly Shuttle Tours and Transportation provides Pearl Harbor Tours and is Oahu’s best airport shuttle and private transportation services company. Their Waikiki to airport shuttles are as low as $13 per person.

To book your tour, call (808) 260-9766 or go to flyshuttlehawaii.com.

Read our review of Fly Shuttle Tour's Beauty and the Feast Tour here.
Tags: around the island|food tour|oahu|oahu tour|scenic views

Title: Alii Agricultural Farms
Content: Fishing Farms Hawaii managed by Ali'i Agriculture Farms, located in Central O’ahu it provides an opportunity to make life time memories. We offer recreational fishing services that is fun for all ages! We have three ponds stocked with healthy tilapia, catfish and grass-carp that we rotate so that each pond does not become over fished. We also have one pond available for prawn fishing. We have a fishing truck that provides a cooking and cleaning service for the fish you catch for an extra fee, or you can buy the fish you've caught and take it home!

Title: Indigo Alliance Hawaii
Content:
A spiritual energy center in the heart of Honolulu's Chinatown, hosting one treatment and two reading rooms and a small inventory for your conscious living necessities.

Living beings have an innate ability to achieve a perfect state of balance in body, mind & spirit. We created Indigo Alliance to help spiritual seekers find their true direction, which is why we aren’t just a bookstore or an event space. Instead, Indigo is a nexus for psychics, spiritual healers, teachers, readers, and seekers who are all working towards evolving both themselves and the world they live in.

Title: Paradise Helicopters - Oahu
Content:
With the grandeur of Oahu Island literally at your feet, Paradise Helicopters takes you above and away for unforgettable views of waterfalls, valleys, volcanoes, coastlines, and beaches. Forget the drone shots—personally experience the thrill of an aerial perspective as you soar above an incredible ever-changing landscape. Add an extra thrill with the doors-off option!

Best of all, Paradise Helicopters offers a Carbon Offset Program if you wish to compensate for the greenhouse gases produced during your tour. One hundred percent of each carbon offset fee is used to plant endemic trees in Hawai‘i! Ask about it when reserving your flight.

Paradise Helicopters has flights daily from JRF airport in Kapolei. Custom charter flights are also available; just speak to one of their specialists who will craft your flight according to your specifications.

Book A Paradise Helicopters Tour Today!

Kapolei: Diamond Head Scenic

Paradise Helicopters’ Diamond Head Scenic tour is the best way to see some of the most famous spots in Hawai‘i by air.

40 Min.

DETAILS

Kapolei: Legends of West Oahu

Get acquainted with Hawaii’s unique cast of characters on the Legends of West Oahu flight.

40 Min.

DETAILS

Kapolei: Oahu Circle Island Experience

Covering the island of Oahu from above, our Circle Island Experience is the only full-circle tour of Oahu by helicopter.

1.25 Hrs.

DETAILS

Kapolei: Oahu Sunset Experience

Follow our popular Circle Island Experience route to enjoy the only full-circle tour of Oahu by helicopter, with the added romance of sunset. 

1.25 Hrs.

DETAILS

Kapolei: Waterfall & Valley Explorer - Doors On

Explore the serenity and beauty of Oahu’s natural areas from the air on Paradise Helicopters’ Waterfall & Valley Explorer tour.

1 Hr.

DETAILS

Turtle Bay: Magnum Experience

Fly the same thrilling route seen in the opening sequence of Magnum, P.I., which takes you offshore above the ocean as you cruise past iconic Waikīkī. 

1 Hr.

DETAILS

Turtle Bay: North Shore Adventure

See all of the breath-taking sights that Oahu’s North Shore has to offer on this 20-minute North Shore Adventure.

20 Min.

DETAILS

Turtle Bay: Valleys & Waterfall Explorer

Explore the serenity and beauty of O‘ahu’s best from the air on Paradise Helicopter’s Valleys & Waterfall Explorer Tour. 

40 Min.

DETAILS

Title: Island Country Markets at Ko Olina
Content: An Island Lifestyle market and gift shop in one. At Island Country Markets – we pride ourselves in offering you our full-service deli. Fresh, crisp salads and tasty gourmet sandwiches, flatbread pizzas with local plate lunch specials daily ~ such as our flavorful Herb Roasted Prime Rib on Thursdays. Include an impressive collection of fine wines and spirits, a great selection of gourmet meats and cheeses, fresh fruits and vegetables alongside a large selection of local and logo apparel, daily needs, groceries, drugs and cosmetics, gifts and souvenirs ~ just about everything you’ll need.

Title: Big Wave Burger Co.
Content:
At Big Wave Burger Company, we’re more than just a food truck. In addition to serving some of Oahu’s juiciest burgers, we strive to serve Aloha daily! If you’re looking for a place with good food, friendly service and a relaxing atmosphere, look no further than Big Wave Burger Company. 

Located in the heart of historic Haleiwa town, one of Hawaii’s most beautiful and picturesque spots, Big Wave Burger Company is sure to add to your experience.  With lots of tables, shade and calming music to add to the ambience, we are sure to make your dining experience one to remember.  Hele Mai, come dine with us! We promise, you’ll be glad you did!
